description: From Latin sequax (“a follower”), from sequi (“to follow”), + -ious (“forming adjectives”).

adjectives.description: sequacious (comparative more sequacious, superlative most sequacious)

entries.meaning: (Of objects, obsolete) Likely to follow or yield to physical pressure; easily shaped or molded.
examples: Of all Fire there is none so ductile, so sequacious and obsequious as this of Wrath.

entries.meaning: (Of people) Likely to follow, conform, or yield to others, especially showing unthinking adherence to others' ideas; easily led.
examples: See how sequacious these poor creatures are to God their Centurion.

entries.meaning: (Of musical notes or poetic feet) Following neatly or smoothly.
examples: And now, its stringsBoldlier swept, the long sequacious notesOver delicious surges sink and rise.

entries.meaning: (Of thought) Following logically or in an unvarying and orderly procession, tending in a single intellectual direction.
examples: Milton was not an extensive or discursive thinker, as Shakespeare was; for the motions of his mind were slow, solemn, and sequacious, like those of the planets.
